children.definition: Always applicable, continuous quarterly monitoring regardless of revolver utilization. 37.9% of covenanted deals. Standard in LMM private credit; rare in UMM/BSL.
children.name: Maintenance Covenants
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 1

children.definition: Percentage of revolving commitments that must be drawn to trigger testing. KCT flags if below 10% availability threshold or greater than 50% dilution.
children.name: Threshold Percentage
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 1; KCT Cat 1 Item 3

children.definition: Undrawn LCs and cash-collateralized LCs excluded from utilization calculation. Reduces effective utilization, making it easier to stay below threshold.
children.name: LC Exclusions
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 1; KCT Cat 1 Item 3

children.definition: Borrowings at closing for OID/expenses excluded from trigger calculation for first 2-4 fiscal quarters. Geneva: first 4 quarters exclude closing-date draws and permitted CoC draws.
children.name: Closing Date Carveouts
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 13 (Closing Date Refinancing); Review Template Row 15 (Revolver closing date draws); KCT Cat 1 Item 2; KCT Cat 1 Item 3; KCT Cat 2 Item 1; KCT Cat 3 Item 12; KCT Cat 3 Item 14

children.definition: How long utilization must exceed threshold before test springs. KCT Cat 1 Item 3 flags if longer than 5 business days consecutive is required. Some deals require sustained breach rather than point-in-time.
children.name: Consecutive Days Requirement
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 1; KCT Cat 1 Item 3; Review Template Row 155 (Financial Statements)

children.definition: Whether unrestricted cash on hand can be netted against drawn revolver amounts when determining utilization for springing purposes. Reduces the effective draw amount, further insulating the borrower.
children.name: Cash Netting
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 1; KCT Cat 1 Item 3

children.definition: Revolver utilization thresholds (35-40%), availability thresholds, and LC exclusions that determine when the springing covenant activates.
children.name: Trigger Mechanisms
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 1; KCT Cat 1 Item 3

children.definition: Whether the springing threshold is measured against total revolving commitments, aggregate revolving exposure, or net revolving availability. Different denominators yield different trigger points for the same dollar draw.
children.name: Springing Denominator
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 1; KCT Cat 1 Item 3

children.definition: How often the springing condition is evaluated. Typically measured at the last day of each fiscal quarter, but some deals allow daily testing (more borrower-friendly as brief spikes do not trigger testing).
children.name: Testing Frequency
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 3; KCT Cat 1 Item 4; KCT Cat 2 Item 1; KCT Cat 2 Item 4; KCT Cat 4 Item 3

children.definition: Tested only when revolving facility is drawn above a specified utilization threshold. 29.3% of covenanted deals. The primary mechanism by which cov-lite structures protect borrowers while preserving nominal lender protections.
children.name: Springing Covenants
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 1; KCT Cat 1 Item 3; Review Template Row 57 (Financial Covenant – application)

children.definition: Covenant applies only to revolving facility, not term loans. Bridge structure between full maintenance and cov-lite: term loan holders have no direct covenant enforcement.
children.name: Revolver-Only Application
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 6 (Revolver); DLS Preferred Row 19 (Revolver); KCT Cat 1 Item 1; Review Template Row 57 (Financial Covenant – application)

children.definition: No maintenance financial covenants on term loans. Incurrence testing only for ratio-conditioned baskets. 53.4% of covenanted deals; 64.5% of full EDGAR corpus. PC line 461: cov-lite typical where closing EBITDA is $60-80M+ range.

market_benchmarks.pctc_bsl: Clients will not assume revolver is fully drawn when setting the level

children.name: Covenant-Lite Structure
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 1; KCT Cat 1 Item 2; KCT Cat 1 Item 3; KCT Cat 1 Item 4; KCT Cat 1 Item 5; KCT Cat 2 Item 1; KCT Cat 2 Item 2; KCT Cat 2 Item 3; KCT Cat 2 Item 4; KCT Cat 3 Item 12; KCT Cat 3 Item 15; KCT Cat 4 Item 1; KCT Cat 4 Item 8

children.definition: Identification of which specific credit facilities within the agreement are subject to ongoing financial covenant testing. In multi-tranche structures, the financial covenant may apply only to revolving facility lenders (springing covenant) while institutional term loan lenders have no maintenance covenant, creating differential protection levels across the capital structure.
children.name: Covenant Facilities
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 1; KCT Cat 1 Item 2; KCT Cat 1 Item 3; KCT Cat 1 Item 4; KCT Cat 1 Item 5; KCT Cat 2 Item 1; KCT Cat 2 Item 3; KCT Cat 2 Item 4; KCT Cat 3 Item 3; KCT Cat 3 Item 4; KCT Cat 3 Item 6; KCT Cat 3 Item 7; KCT Cat 3 Item 8; KCT Cat 3 Item 11; KCT Cat 3 Item 13; KCT Cat 3 Item 15; KCT Cat 4 Item 1; KCT Cat 4 Item 3; KCT Cat 4 Item 7; KCT Cat 4 Item 10; KCT Cat 5 Item 1; PC Term Comparison, 2. Article 2 (Incremental Facilities)

children.definition: Financial covenant applies only to pro rata tranches (revolver and Term A), excluding institutional Term B and incremental facilities. Standard in BSL transactions where CLO investors prefer covenant-lite structures while bank lenders retain covenant protection.
children.name: Pro Rata Only
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 1; KCT Cat 1 Item 2; KCT Cat 1 Item 3; KCT Cat 1 Item 4; KCT Cat 1 Item 5; KCT Cat 2 Item 3; KCT Cat 3 Item 3; KCT Cat 3 Item 6; KCT Cat 3 Item 7; KCT Cat 3 Item 13; KCT Cat 4 Item 1; KCT Cat 4 Item 4; KCT Cat 4 Item 7; KCT Cat 4 Item 8; KCT Cat 4 Item 10; KCT Cat 5 Item 1

children.definition: When, how, and to which facilities financial covenants apply. DLS Preferred row 73 preferred position: full-time testing across all facilities. Alternative: covenant-lite (revolver only), tested only when revolving loans and letters of credit exceed a threshold (30-35% of commitments). Under covenant-lite, 'Only lenders holding at least a majority of the loans and commitments under the Revolving Facility shall have the ability to amend the financial covenant and waive a breach,' and term loan EoD occurs only after revolver lenders terminate commitments and accelerate. Review Template row 57 confirms: 'Covenant applies to the revolver only and springs when utilization exceeds agreed thresholds. Term loan default should occur only if the revolver accelerates and terminates commitments.' PC Term Comparison: TTS transactions likely covenant-lite where closing EBITDA is in $60-80M+ range.

children.definition: Total debt net of unrestricted cash divided by EBITDA. 75.4% of covenanted deals. Dominant test type. DealData median initial level 7.75x across 45 deals.

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 62 (Leverage Ratio Calculations); KCT Cat 1 Item 2; KCT Cat 1 Item 3; KCT Cat 1 Item 8; KCT Cat 2 Item 1; KCT Cat 2 Item 2; KCT Cat 4 Item 5; KCT Cat 4 Item 8; KCT Cat 4 Item 12; PC Term Comparison, 1. children.definition: First lien debt divided by EBITDA. 19.3% of covenanted deals. Standard in CMM/UMM private credit where senior secured debt is the relevant measure.
children.name: First Lien Leverage
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 146 (Cross-default)

children.definition: Total (gross) debt divided by EBITDA. 5.3% of covenanted deals. More restrictive than net leverage as no cash netting. DLS preferred includes this test.
children.name: Total Leverage
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios)

children.definition: Secured debt divided by EBITDA. 3.5% of covenanted deals. Risk-based collateral focus — captures all secured obligations regardless of lien priority.
children.name: Secured Leverage
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 2 Item 1; KCT Cat 2 Item 2; KCT Cat 3 Item 15; KCT Cat 4 Item 8; KCT Cat 4 Item 10; KCT Cat 4 Item 11; KCT Cat 4 Item 12; KCT Cat 5 Item 1

children.definition: Debt-to-EBITDA ceiling the borrower must not exceed. The dominant covenant type at 82.5% of covenanted deals. Variants differ by numerator: total net, first lien net, secured net, or total gross.
children.name: Maximum Leverage Ratio
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 41 (Maximum leverage)

FIN_COV_LEVERAGE_RATIO.label: Financial Covenant - Leverage Ratio Levels

FLNLR and SNLR only include debt secured by liens
semanticVariants: maximum first lien net leverage ratio

exactPhrases: Maximum First Lien Net Leverage Ratio
FLNLR and SNLR only include debt secured by liens
semanticVariants: maximum first lien net leverage ratio

children.definition: EBIT or EBITDA divided by interest expense floor. Traditional coverage metric increasingly rare in modern leveraged finance. DLS preferred includes interest coverage; market is moving away.
children.name: Minimum Interest Coverage
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 18 (Interest Rates)

children.definition: EBITDA divided by fixed charges (interest + scheduled principal + capex + taxes + distributions). Primary coverage metric where used. DLS preferred: included. 10.5% of covenanted deals have any coverage test.
children.name: Minimum Fixed Charge Coverage
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 3; KCT Cat 2 Item 1; KCT Cat 2 Item 4; KCT Cat 4 Item 6

children.definition: Separate first-lien-specific leverage ceiling distinct from total leverage test. Applied where capital structure has multiple lien tiers. Tests senior secured debt only against EBITDA.
children.name: Maximum First Lien Leverage
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 41 (Maximum leverage); Review Template Row 144 (Cushions to first lien); KCT Cat 2 Item 1; KCT Cat 2 Item 2; KCT Cat 2 Item 3; KCT Cat 3 Item 15; KCT Cat 4 Item 4; KCT Cat 4 Item 12; Learning Material (FIRST LIEN I SECOND LIEN INTERCREDITOR AGREEMENTS); Learning Material (Business Points in 1L/2L ICAs CAP ON FIRST LIEN OBLIGATIONS)

children.definition: Annual capex ceiling. DLS preferred includes this test. Rare in modern private credit — only found in heavily covenanted LMM deals. Often has carryover provisions for unused amounts.
children.name: Maximum Capital Expenditures
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 3; KCT Cat 2 Item 1; KCT Cat 2 Item 4; KCT Cat 3 Item 7; KCT Cat 3 Item 13; KCT Cat 4 Item 6

children.definition: Minimum cash plus available revolving commitments. 10.5% of EDGAR deals. Non-ratio covenant based on absolute dollar floor. Includes broad liquidity definition (cash + revolver availability, sometimes including ABL availability).
children.name: Minimum Liquidity
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 43 (Minimum ratings)

FIN_COV_MINIMUM_LIQUIDITY.label: Financial Covenant - Minimum Liquidity
exactPhrases: available commitments under the Revolving Facility
available commitments under the Revolving Facility

children.definition: The specific financial metrics that the borrower must satisfy. DLS Preferred row 73 lists four covenant types: (1) Total [Net] Leverage Ratio with step-downs; (2) Senior [Secured] [Net] Leverage Ratio with step-downs; (3) Fixed Charge Coverage Ratio; and (4) Maximum Capital Expenditures. PC Term Comparison: 'Should be a Total Leverage Ratio' for covenant-lite structures. The leverage covenant is the primary tool, while coverage and capex covenants provide additional oversight. Review Template row 58 notes levels are set with 'cushions to the sponsor model and step-downs.'

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 73 (Covenant); Review Template Row 57 (Financial Covenant – application); KCT Cat 1

children.definition: How cushion is defined and measured. Expressed as a percentage below the sponsor's projected EBITDA for the relevant test period. DLS Row 73: '[X]% non cumulative cushion to EBITDA from the Sponsor's model.' Non-cumulative means each quarter's cushion is independently sized.
children.name: Cushion Definition
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 3; KCT Cat 2 Item 1; KCT Cat 2 Item 4; KCT Cat 3 Item 13

children.definition: Opening cushion percentage at closing. LMM deals: 25-30%. UMM/aggressive: 35%+. The cushion is only as protective as the model is conservative — aggressive EBITDA addbacks inflate the model, making the cushion look adequate when the true margin for error is thinner.
children.name: Initial Cushion Level
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 6; KCT Cat 1 Item 7; KCT Cat 2 Item 1; KCT Cat 2 Item 4

children.definition: Whether and how the cushion narrows over time as step-downs tighten the covenant level. In deals with step-downs, the cushion may remain constant (level steps down tracking the model) or compress (level steps down faster than model deleveraging).
children.name: Cushion Tightening
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 3; KCT Cat 1 Item 4; KCT Cat 2 Item 4; KCT Cat 3 Item 12; KCT Cat 3 Item 15; KCT Cat 4 Item 1; KCT Cat 4 Item 3; KCT Cat 4 Item 5

children.definition: Cushion specific to the first lien leverage test. Typically tighter than total leverage cushion because the first lien ratio has a lower denominator (excludes junior debt).
children.name: First Lien Cushion
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 144 (Cushions to first lien)

children.definition: Whether second lien, mezzanine, or holdco facilities have baskets and incurrence ratios cushioned relative to the senior debt financial covenant. Typically 0.5-1.0x wider than first lien covenant level.
children.name: Second Lien / Subordinated Cushion
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 4; Review Template Row 143 (Second Lien Facility); Review Template Row 144 (Cushions to first lien); Review Template Row 145 (Anti-layering); Review Template Row 146 (Cross-default); Review Template Row 147 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: The gap between the financial maintenance covenant test level and the borrower's projected leverage ratio (from the sponsor model), providing headroom for underperformance before a covenant breach occurs. DLS Preferred row 74 specifies a '[___]% non cumulative cushion to EBITDA from the Sponsor's model.' PC Term Comparison provides segment-specific guidance: 'For Cov Lite: Ranges of cushions to sponsor model: 35-40% off sponsor model. Unlike BSL Clients will not assume revolver is fully drawn when setting the level.' For full-time covenant: 'Typically at a non-cumulative cushion of [30-35]% off sponsor model.' Review Template row 58 similarly notes cushion to sponsor model. The cushion is non-cumulative, meaning each period's cushion is calculated independently against the model without reference to prior periods.
children.name: Cushion Mechanics

negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market standard for cushion / covenant levels reflects a negotiated middle ground, with specific terms varying by deal size, leverage profile, and competitive dynamics.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: [ ]% non cumulative cushion to EBITDA from the Sponsor's model.

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 74 (non-cumulative cushion specification); PC Term Comparison Financial Covenant section lines 463-471 (cov-lite 35-40%, full-time 30-35%, revolver assumption differences)
children.market_benchmarks: PC Term Comparison: Cov-Lite 35-40% off sponsor model (revolver not assumed fully drawn); Full-Time 30-35% non-cumulative off sponsor model. DLS Preferred: [___]% non-cumulative cushion.

children.definition: The revolving facility utilization percentage above which the maintenance covenant is tested. Standard: 35-40% of revolving commitments. Expert extractions: Geneva 40%, Rinchem 40%, Scientific Games 40%.
children.name: Springing Threshold
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 1; KCT Cat 1 Item 3

children.definition: Base against which utilization is measured. Options include aggregate revolving commitments, revolving exposure, or net revolving availability. The denominator choice determines the effective trigger level.
children.name: Springing Denominator
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 1; KCT Cat 1 Item 3

children.definition: Whether unrestricted cash on the balance sheet can offset drawn revolver amounts when determining utilization for springing purposes. If allowed, a borrower with $50M drawn on a $100M revolver but $20M cash is treated as $30M utilized.
children.name: Cash Netting for Trigger
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 1; KCT Cat 1 Item 3

children.definition: How LCs are counted in utilization: excluded entirely, included only if drawn, or included at face amount. Cash-collateralized LCs almost always excluded. Undrawn LCs typically excluded in borrower-favorable deals.
children.name: Letter of Credit Treatment
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 1

children.definition: How often the springing condition is evaluated. Standard: last day of each fiscal quarter. Aggressive: only at quarterly reporting dates. Conservative: daily measurement period (any day above threshold triggers test).
children.name: Testing Frequency
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 3

children.definition: Framework governing when and how springing covenants activate. Under covenant-lite structures, the financial maintenance covenant only springs when revolving facility utilization exceeds an agreed threshold. DLS Preferred row 73 alternative specifies the covenant is 'Only tested if on the last day of a fiscal quarter revolving loans and letters of credit (excluding (i) undrawn letters of credit in an amount not to exceed $[___] million and (ii) drawn letters of credit that are 100% cash collateralized or backstopped) are outstanding in an aggregate amount exceeding an amount equal to [30/35%] of the total amount of the commitments under the Revolving Facility then in effect.' PC Term Comparison specifies: 'Tripped when 35-40% drawn. Only exclude cash collateralized LCs and perhaps up to $x of non-cash collateralized LCs. Reject request to test usage net of cash. Standstill should apply.' KCT Category 1 item 3 identifies springing trigger issues including thresholds exceeding 40%, fixed size thresholds, cash netting of drawn amounts, capex exclusions, and repayment after period-end to avoid testing.
children.name: Springing Mechanics

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Revolver Only and Covenant Lite: Only tested if on the last day of a fiscal quarter revolving loans and letters of credit (excluding (i) undrawn letters of credit in an amount not to exceed $[ ] million and (ii) drawn letters of credit that are 100% cash collateralized or backstopped) are outstanding in an aggregate amount exceeding an amount equal to [30/35%] of the total amount of the commitment
key_negotiation_points: Financial covenant applies only to revolving facility
Term loan cross-default from covenant breach
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market standard for financial covenant type & testing reflects a negotiated middle ground, with specific terms varying by deal size, leverage profile, and competitive dynamics.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: No springing covenant; full maintenance testing at all times. Reject revolver-draw-based springing trigger

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 73 (springing threshold mechanics: 30/35% of commitments, LC exclusions); PC Term Comparison Financial Covenant section lines 465-468 (35-40% drawn, reject net of cash); KCT Category 1 item 3 (five springing trigger risk issues)

children.definition: When the compliance certificate must be delivered after quarter-end. Typically within 45 days for quarterly financials and 90 days for annual financials. Late delivery can itself constitute an Event of Default under information covenants.
children.name: Delivery Timing
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 4; Review Template Row 52 (Financial Statements – quarterly); Review Template Row 54 (Financial Statements – annual audits)

children.definition: Level of detail required in the compliance calculation. Must include covenant ratio computation, EBITDA build-up with addbacks, net debt calculation, and statement of compliance or non-compliance.
children.name: Calculation Detail
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 4

children.definition: Which officers must sign (typically CFO or equivalent), the standard of certification (knowledge-based or absolute), and whether personal liability attaches to misstatements.
children.name: Officer Certification
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 4

children.definition: Whether the borrower may deliver corrected compliance certificates that retroactively demonstrate compliance after initially reporting a breach. Related to deemed cure (KCT Cat 1 Item 4).
children.name: Retroactive Correction
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 4

children.definition: Quarterly officer certificate demonstrating financial covenant compliance with detailed calculations. DLS Preferred row 78 affirmative covenants clause (vii) requires delivery of 'quarterly compliance certificates and other information.' The compliance certificate is the primary document through which the administrative agent and lenders verify whether the borrower satisfies its maintenance covenant levels, attaching computation of all tested ratios (leverage, coverage, capex). Review Template row 56 notes delivery should accompany quarterly financial statements with extended windows for initial post-closing periods.

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 78 clause (vii) (quarterly compliance certificates in affirmative covenants); Review Template rows 52/56 (quarterly delivery and affirmative covenant framework)

children.definition: The measurement period for financial covenant calculations. Standard: trailing four fiscal quarters (LTM). Some deals allow annualization of partial periods near closing.
children.name: Test Period
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 1; KCT Cat 1 Item 2; KCT Cat 1 Item 3; KCT Cat 1 Item 4; KCT Cat 1 Item 5; KCT Cat 2 Item 1; KCT Cat 2 Item 2; KCT Cat 2 Item 3; KCT Cat 3 Item 12; KCT Cat 4 Item 1

children.name: Pro Forma Testing

children.definition: Initial period post-closing (typically 2-4 quarters) during which the financial covenant is not tested or is tested at relaxed levels. children.definition_source: Review Template Row 59 (Financial Covenant – testing thresholds)

children.definition: Quarterly, semi-annual, or annual adjustments on pre-set schedule. Most common structure. Typical step: 0.25x reduction per year.

children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 4; KCT Cat 2 Item 4; KCT Cat 4 Item 3

children.definition: Triggered by EBITDA growth, debt reduction milestones, or other financial performance metrics rather than the passage of time.

children.definition: The quantum of each step-down. Standard: 0.25x per year (e.g., 5.75x to 5.50x to 5.25x). Aggressive: 0.125x or smaller increments. Conservative: 0.50x steps.

children.definition: The event or date that activates each step-down. Options include fixed calendar dates, anniversary of closing, or fiscal quarter-end dates. Some deals use EBITDA milestones as alternative triggers.

children.definition: Progressive tightening of covenant levels over time, requiring the borrower to delever post-acquisition. DLS Preferred row 73 specifies 'Total [Net] Leverage Ratio with step downs' and 'Senior [Secured] [Net] Leverage Ratio with step downs.' PC Term Comparison: for full-time covenants, 'Most likely static but may get 1-2 25bps stepdowns.' Step-downs reflect the expectation that leverage should decrease as the borrower generates cash flow and prepays debt. The presence and schedule of step-downs signals the anticipated deleveraging path agreed between the sponsor and lender group.
children.name: Step-Down Schedules

children.definition: Types of debt excluded from the financial covenant calculation, effectively allowing the borrower to take on non-counted debt. KCT Category 1 item 5 flags as a risk concern: 'Debt incurred under fixed baskets (such as freebie, non-guarantor debt basket, general debt basket, or acquisition debt basket) excluded or allowed to be excluded from calculating compliance with financial covenant.' This creates a wedge between the covenant leverage ratio and actual economic leverage. The exclusion mechanism can operate through the definition of Total Indebtedness (excluding certain basket debt) or through the covenant testing mechanics (excluding concurrent draws).

children.definition: Financial covenant breaches can be waived by Required Lenders (typically >50% of commitments). children.definition: Provision treating an equity cure contribution as automatically remedying the covenant breach without requiring formal lender acknowledgment, waiver, or amendment. children.definition: Risk concern per KCT Category 1 item 1: '(a) No financial covenants for RCFs or TLAs or (b) breach of financial covenants only applies as a condition to Borrowing and will not result in an Event of Default (i.e., breaching the financial covenant results only in a drawstop of any unfunded committed amount).' This means covenant breach merely prevents new draws rather than triggering acceleration, eliminating the primary enforcement mechanism. PC Term Comparison notes that KCT item 10 separately flags: 'The existence of a Default should prohibit any borrowing of loans -- i.e., there should be no ability to borrow any loans if a Default is continuing.' When combined with a drawstop-only covenant, the lender loses both the enforcement tool and the information forcing function.

market_benchmarks.standard: Revolver draw-stop only, no event of default for financial covenant breach

children.name: Drawstop-only consequence (no EoD)
children.definition_source: KCT Category 1 item 1 (no financial covenants or drawstop-only consequence); KCT Category 3 item 10 (Default should prohibit all borrowings)

definition: Financial maintenance covenants tested periodically (typically quarterly on the last day of each fiscal quarter for the trailing four-quarter period) to ensure the borrower meets minimum financial performance standards. DLS Preferred position: full-time testing of Total Net Leverage Ratio with step-downs, Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio with step-downs, Fixed Charge Coverage Ratio, and Maximum Capital Expenditures, commencing with the first full fiscal quarter after closing. Alternative (covenant-lite) formulation: testing only if revolving loans and LCs (excluding undrawn LCs up to an agreed amount and 100% cash-collateralized LCs) exceed 30-35% of total revolving commitments. In covenant-lite, only revolving facility lenders holding a majority of revolving loans/commitments can amend or waive the financial covenant, and a breach does not constitute a term loan EoD until revolving lenders have actually terminated commitments and accelerated. PC Term Comparison: for cov-lite, cushion is 35-40% off sponsor model (unlike BSL, PC clients do not assume revolver is fully drawn when setting levels); for full-time covenant, 30-35% non-cumulative cushion off sponsor model, typically a static Total Leverage Ratio with possibly 1-2 step-downs of 25bps.
